misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student correctly understands the logic required for a cyclic right shift: save the last element, iterate backward from n-1 down to 1 (inclusive), moving a[i-1] to a[i], and finally place the saved last element into a[0].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap. The student's code correctly implements the specified right-shift logic, including the wrap-around, using a temporary variable to hold the last element before the shifting loop overwrites it.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student correctly understands the necessary steps for a right array rotation: saving the last element, shifting elements from the end of the array backward (a[i] = a[i-1]), and finally placing the saved element into the first position (a[0]). The use of a temporary variable to hold the wrapping element and the correct boundary conditions for the backwards loop (starting at n-1 and stopping when i > 0, ensuring a[1] = a[0] is the last copy operation) demonstrate an accurate mental model for this specific algorithm.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap (the implementation is logically correct according to Java's execution model and achieves the required right shift functionality). The student understands that array assignment is purely sequential and requires temporary storage to prevent overwriting critical data (the wrap-around element).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error. The code produces the correct output.
